preface.title: Preface
preface.para: This guide provides an introduction to Sapo-Broker and what it is about. 1

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Sapo-Broker is a high performance distributed messaging framework. It can either work as a local daemon or embedded within your application. Among other features, it provides minimal administration overhead, Publish-Subscribe and Point-to-Point messaging, guaranteed delivery and wildcard subscriptions.
Sapo-Broker is written in Java and has client libraries for Java, Perl, Python, PHP, Ruby, .NET, C and Erlang.

section.title: Messaging
section.para: When talking about messaging we are really talking about asynchronous, distributed and reliable operations. This means that broker clients can register interest in "Destinations" and return immediately, also a client can be notified in an event-driven fashion when something has happened. This allows for a loosely coupled exchange of messages between producers and consumers since they know nothing of each other, they only know about destinations (queues and topics). Immediate benefits of using messaging are:

itemizedlist.listitem: Fire and Forget: Producers don't wait for consumers, as soon as the broker receives the message they may return immediately.
Clients Independence: Consumers don't know about producers and producers don't know about consumers. Don't know who they are, where they are located and what technology they use.
Scalability: Messages in a single stream can be handled in parallel by many client threads or systems.

Robustness to Change: Applications on heterogeneous platforms communicate and interoperate transparently yet each application operates independently of, and asynchronously with, others. Communicating programs remain separately maintained and individually replaceable.
Time Independence: Neither the message sender nor the message recipient needs to be online at the same time. The Broker queues messages when their recipients are not available.
Sapo-Broker supports publish-subscribe and point-to-point communication, as well durable topic subscription.
Subscriptions may be defined as regular expressions (also know as wildcard subscriptions).
Clients libraries are available in several languages and platforms such as Java, Perl, Python, PHP, Ruby, .NET, C and Erlang.
Several message encoding protocols are supported (XML, Thrift and Google Protocol Buffers) and more can be easily added.
The number of agents constituting a communicating cloud is easily scalable thus providing system scalability and availability.
Access control policies can be defined to constrain message production or consumption based in several criteria including role-based authorization.
Agents support SSL connections to clients.
Message dropbox (a directory where files containing messages are saved by clients and forward by agents) is available.

section.title: Supported broker topologies
section.para: Message brokers, depending on specific products, can be configured to implement different topologies, such as hierarchical, network, single broker or a mixture of the previous.

Sapo-Broker can be used as a single instance or in network topology. Although a single agent instance could be used in small working sets, a multiple agent (network) design would better take advantage of Sapo-Broker, namely in system availability and throughput, with client failover and distributed workload, respectively. In networking topologies all agents are interconnected in what is known as agent cloud. Is is not yet possible to communicate between different agent clouds.

section.title: Message publication and subscription
section.para: When designing and implementing messaging-based solutions two main paradigms exist: Point-to-Point and Publish-Subscribe. Just like Java Message Service (JMS) we use the terms "TOPIC" to refer Publish-Subscribe Destinations and "QUEUE" to designate Point-to-Point Destinations. Sapo-Broker supports Â both of these patterns and adds special purpose Destination Type named "VIRTUAL_QUEUE" witch stands somewhere in between.

A publication, in general terms, contains a Destination Type (TOPIC or QUEUE) which determines the pattern intended is, and a Destination Name witch may be a Topic or Queue name. Subscriptions, on the other hand, include a Destination Type (TOPIC, QUEUE or VIRTUAL_QUEUE) and a Destination witch is a subscription name, meaning that can be a Topic or Queue name or a regular expression (wildcard subscription) agglomerating several Topics.
A use case regarding topic, queues and virtual queues is available.

section.title: Publish-Subscribe
section.para: Messages published to the Destination Type "TOPIC" adhere to the Publish-Subscribe pattern, that is, they are delivered to any consumer subscribed in the published Destination Name. That is, they can be delivered to zero or many consumers, regardless if they are connected to the same agent as the producer or a remote one. If there are no remote clients, the local agent doesn't forward the message.

Message producers, using this pattern, don't have no know what applications are interested in a particular type of message. Producers just publish events notifying of some notable occurrence and applications subscribed to it based on their needs.

section.title: Point-to-Point
section.para: When using Point-to-Point messaging, delivery is load balanced across many consumers, meaning each message goes to exactly one consumer. Consumers compete for messages and must send an acknowledgement after successfully processing the message. This pattern is useful when one wants to distribute jobs across many workers.

section.title: Virtual Queues
section.para: Events published as TOPIC messages lack the ability to be persisted and QUEUE messages, once consumed by a client, can not be consumed by another. This means that if there are two systems interested in the same type of information published to queues, the two systems wouldn't received the same messages.

To overcome these handicaps Sapo-Broker supports VIRTUAL_QUEUE Destination Type. When clients subscribe to a topic as a Virtual Queue an ordinary queue is created and all topic messages whose Destination Name match the subscription are stored in the created queue. Virtual Queues are also known as durable subscriptions.

section.title: Message Queues
section.para: Queues implement reliable load balancing with persistence. Messages are only removed from the Queue after the broker receives an acknowledge, so if a consumer crashes during the processing of a message it is redelivered to another consumer. Clients have a limited time to acknowledge message processing during witch the message is guaranteed not be delivered to other client, the message is reserved. The first time the message is delivered local consumers have priority.
